Open thread • Replies: 9 • Updated: 2026-02-18 22:39 UTC

OP

Its ridiculous the woman at our workplace contribute nothing to the company and make more money than i do
Its infuriating we just had a bunch of lay offs and we lost some of oir best workers but somehow a bunch of HR shits who do nothing all day still work here

Early replies (first 3)

61871530
HR is a necessary function, chud

61871569
>>61871530
For what?
Genuinely why do we need it to this extent?

61871755
>>61871569
Protect the corp from lawsuits

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61871931
>OP is letting an australian skincare companies satire social media post bother him enough to make a post about it.
anon they saw you get pissed off on their first vid and are just continuing a bit. they don't ACTUALLY do nothing. they are a marketing team. and you are a shill promoting their content. you are more fake and gay than they are.

61871937
>>61871569
Benefits is needed to keep people from leaving and to entice new applicants. HR is needed because of what >>61871755 said. The part of hr that does need to be eradicated is the hiring team. HR is sadly needed but they put in a bunch of bullshit. HR is a reflection of the legal system because they are only there to make sure the company doesn't go bankrupt from getting sued out the ass. Make the courts and judges less gay and then you can downsize HR because the risk isn't as high.

61871939
>>61871520
>this is a good dance, a skillful execution of dance moves.

61871942
>>61871520
Yes, we sent rejection emails out from Workday 1 day later.
Yes, we still pay to promote that position 4 months later.
Yes, Santa should have wrapped that LinkedIn posting.
Yes, Santa sent it early.

61871955
One last thing. LinkedIn and Indeed are fucking retarded for not forcing companies to pay to post their job postings.
>Ensures the job postings are actually legit
>Additional revenue source
>Insider knowledge on the industries ACTUALLY hiring

61872023

Open thread • Replies: 3 • Updated: 2026-02-18 22:40 UTC

Early replies (first 3)

61872000
I was. And fyi it doesn’t have to be a 401k. You can just have a traditional IRA and deposit and convert from there. Only thing is you can’t have any other IRA accounts w/ pretax contributions otherwise it triggers pro rule rule.

But to answer your question, I no longer contribute because retirement accounts won’t exist 10 years from now let alone 20+. I’m prob going to cash out mine and take the penalty in the fall if we have a low income year

Check myself

61871884
The thing is in 2014, 2017, 2021 you could take 10,000 bucks and buy basically anything and a 10x was guaranteed.

I remember taking 2021 for granted lol.

The 2024 bull run saw an initial pump from alts from january to april and then htey just bled from april to september, then bled again from december to may, and from may 2025 to present the bulk of alts bled out.

I remember seeing microstrategy and I was like "gonna buy that when bitcoin goes back to 50k". Then I saw MSTX. Hell yeah, double your money for each MSTR move, and MSTR was double bitcoin. A run to 100k from 50k would be an easy 8x. And it was. But I sold before the election and fumbled it. The fumbler. It's easy to create a perfect plan in your mind, and watch it play out exactly as you said it would, but it takes a lot of conviction to not fuck it up.

Now most markets are way up. 2026, 2022, 2018, midterm years have slow market growth. The time to buy it was 2023, the time to make it was 2024, the time to swap into alts like KTA and HYPE and AVANTIS was 2025. I called everything correctly but fucked up the one thing that mattered- buying, and holding to a 10x.

61871888
>>61871780

item.title: Is it really that much more difficult to start a business in the eu than us? — 75 replies — 69.6/hr
item.content:encoded:
Is it really that much more difficult to start a business in the eu than us?

Open thread • Replies: 75 • Updated: 2026-02-18 21:37 UTC

OP

You guys in the EU make less than us on paychecks, but you get to keep more of your money because you have universal healthcare and PTO while we have to pay for private insurance which chronically denies people's health situations.

Are people saying that starting a business in the EU is difficult because of the regulations? What regulations does the European union impose on its citizen's than they think it's easier to start in the United States instead?

Early replies (first 3)

61860815
>>61860796
Depends enormously on which country are we talking about. Some are easy (Germany) some are very hard (Italy)

61860817
>>61860796
> you get to keep more of your money because you have universal healthcare
yeah right
good luck getting that "universal healthcare" if you're not a boomer, waiting lists are years for even a basic exam/procedure. It's either you go private (and pay out of your own pocket) or you die
> and PTO
oh wow, 20 wagie cagie free days a year. Totally worth the 60%+ taxes.

All taxation is theft. It's just that. Taxation doesn't pay for services. It's just the way they control the economy, and here in EU they fucking LOVE to control what you can and cannot do. They print the money, they don't need to tax you. They tax you to control you (and to humiliate you)

>>61860796
The healthcare thing is too much american leftie argument, it also has been very overcrowded by you guessed arabs and africans, unironically I was better treated when I broke my leg in brazil of all places then in france

it started long before post-WW2 tho, germs bureaucracymaxxed post-reunification during the 2nd Reich, from 1871 onward.
At first it was to keep in check all the landers trying to take the lion's share of federal credits and centralize power. And it worked gud, but then it progressively became the hellscape kafkaian machine we all know.
That's how you know the hallofcost never happened, becuz you can be sure nazis would have made endless paperworks addressing the situation, down to the very last jewish pubic hair, but we didn't find any document.

61870778
Stop eating the commie propaganda. Europeans don't have savings for shit, they just have stable expenses but all their wealth is tied to inheriting homes. That's why homes are basically untaxed while stocks are treated like financial Nazism. You aren't going to spend more a healthy young person in the US, the real benefit of Europe is the private healthcare is very cheap and good

Starting businesses in Europe sucks because of two factors. The first is low liquidity and consumer spending: unlike the US, people don't spend nearly as much, have as much to spend, or make debt. So there isn't much room for anyone to buy something new - successful businesses target liquid tourists or B2B, where they write off the huge taxes as expenses. Over regulated financial market also leads to lower liquidity and more difficulty getting loans and investors, you rely on government programs run by middle aged menopausal cunts that have never worked more than 28 hours a week

Other issue is labor laws and public perception. It's morally bankrupt to try and get more money, why aren't you happy being average, why are you trying to pull ahead. Anyone you hire can't be fired, you can't have low compensation with offset packages to get high skill labor, you need to suck some blue blooded cock to get money and not wait years for whatever permits you'll need, because they were born out of nobility and still have half the money and connections

Eurotards freak out about Epstein but every European politician and rich person rapes babies for breakfast. It's just 1) not pedo to them if they're over 14 bc muh age of consent and 2) they hide in the shadows unlike Americans, they try to be as unnoticed as possible, give a few concessions to the poor and continue ruling sucking and fucking like they've been doing the past thousand years

>>61869942
Yeah i feel the same. Sex, drugs and love are already the ultimate sensations and none of them are expensive. All luxuries are pretty worthless add-ons and don’t feel special. You just have a bigger bed, or a bigger car, not anything you really need.

61870937
>>61860817
That's complete bullshit, stop making up fantasies in your mind. If there is ONE thing still somewhat running smoothly in western Europe, it's free healthcare.
Contrary to you i know what i'm talking about since i was on the operation table just a month ago to fix few lower vertebrae after a bike accident. I never had to wait for anything more than few days, nor did i have to spend a single penny on pre-procedures, examinations or for the hospital stay/operation/anesthesia/post-op medication. And i don't have any health mutual.

It probably would have costed me a bazillion goybux in the jewSA.

61871000
>>61870937

Also if the accident wasn't your fault you could sue for big money, in Europe they're just like meh accidents happen enjoy the lifelong complications faggot. I will agree southern European health systems are pretty decent and their private healthcare is fantastic and cheap, but if you're German or some shit I'd rather have the US system, you guys pay more in healthcare tax than any American if you have a half decent job and if you get anything where you may actually die they just say, yeah you're fucked settle your affairs or the bureaucracy will give the rest of your family a stroke, no point trying any more it's an inefficient allocation of resources

>>61868041
This is extremely short-sighted of them, they will end up losing the capacity to compete and fall behind slowly, they actually already are, then when they slowly go on closing business left and right from ever increasing ineficiency. What else can they even do but borrow more and more for the worst possible spending a state can do, paying bills, a budget blackhole, increasing inflation and making money useless and as those countries get poorer the services will also get far far far worse and extremely corrupt, not even talking about how such aging will make it even worse. Honestly this is reading like what happened to argentina, greece and other latam and thirdies socialist govts did, it will work fine as long as the economy can keep it, when it starts to shrink it will be poverty hell. I will agree that america treats us workers pretty bad, but this welfare paradise of the EU won't work for long either, they will end up forced to cut things and get closer to us if they want to survive a world with China, India, US and former colonies being no longer mudhutts but mildly developed enough to make raw resources more expensive.

61871023
>>61860796
Lots of retards ITT.

Setting up a business is child's play in places like Denmark, Sweden, Estonia. Setting up, doing tax returns and all interactions with gov is handled through online ID and takes seconds.

Places like Bulgaria, Romania, Slovenia are selling themselves as business friendly. Very low taxes. Some places like Bulgaria have extremely low dividend taxes so you pay yourself with dividends. Romania has a corporate setup where you pay a tiny percentage on the turnover. Ideal for freelancers or small business with high margins or just extreme low expense. In all of these places, corporate setups and accountants cost next to nothing.

Then you have some almost offshore jurisdictions still in the EU with insanely beneficial rules for some niches and very low taxes. Like Cyprus and Malta.

Now regulations, what regulations? Anything (except guns, booze, some gambling, cigarettes I guess) is traded freely between the states under the same legislation.

Also: we get sued way less over here. Do the math on that one.

61871050

> French government instantly asks her for €800, before she has made her first sale
> this is what they estimate she'd owe them at the end of the year based on their estimates of how much she will earn, so they ask for it upfront
> you can contest it but it's actually faster to wait for the year to end so they are proven wrong
I hate them so much...

item.title: Oldfags on this board... what was it like hunting for a job in 2021-2022 ? — 37 replies — 26.5/hr
item.content:encoded:
Oldfags on this board... what was it like hunting for a job in 2021-2022 ?

Open thread • Replies: 37 • Updated: 2026-02-18 21:17 UTC

OP

>be me
>zoomer wagie stuck in application hell
>look at the linkedin of every mid-level manager/engineer at FAANG/Fortune 500
>notice a pattern
>literally every single one of them (mostly jeets/chinks) got hired between 2020-2022 while I was still in high school
>mfw

Is it just me or was the bar literally on the floor back then? What was the "process" even like for you dinosaurs? Did you just walk in, pulse check, firm handshake, and get handed a 250k TC package with stock options?

Explain to me how you guys actually got hired during the infinite money glitch era without sounding like you just got lucky.

Early replies (first 3)

61868988
>>61868983
they reached out to me from LinkedIn and asked me to interview. I interviewed with them, passed the interview and then they hired me. They asked me to fill out the job application paperwork after I already did a few interviews to "make it official". Then I got an offer for close to 400k TC and took it.

61869002
>>61868983
Nobody wanted to work because covid relief was so good. You could make more on unemploymenr than working and you could put off paying a lot of your bills. Getting a job was easy if you wanted one.

61869003
>>61868983
I graduated with a degree in Physics in December 2019. Covid hit early 2020. I worked at a gas station for 4 months before getting factory work. I worked on the factory floor for all of covid, and only got a job in my field in 2023. It was hell.

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61869094
got a random email one day asking me if I wanted to join their company, no resume or anything, and thats where I am today

61869113
>>61868983
I started applaying for a new job in jan 21 and in april i landed a new one with 50% increase. After a few months i started applying again and in 22 i got a remote job with almost 100% salary increase and a more favourable taxation. This kind of leap is the easiest early in your career, it gets much more difficult later.

61869617
>>61869023
This. I took that first $120k position and ran with it. I worked my other job too though so $120k + $75k. The job laid off 30% of the company in a year though.
>>61868983
It was crazy, multiple recruiters in your DMs on linkedin a day. Always got an interview if you applied. Everything was remote nearly and good pay. Feels like you were the hot HS QB for a year then you graduated, got fat and forgotten about. I went to get my PhD in the mean time.

61869636
>>61868983
i'm an accountingfag not a techfag. that said, the job market in 2021 was very good. at the time i only had 3 YOE and i would get like 15-20 recruiter messages a month. i interviewed all over for remote jobs. today, even with more experience and several promotions to management, i'm lucky to get like 5 recruiter messages a month and all of the jobs sound like shit (remote is rare.)

61869678
>>61869636
CPA here
Governmentmaxxing
Pensionmaxxing
Comfymaxxing

Biggest challenge in government is once you bet high enough, you’re working closely with elected officials who have totally different perspective than normal people

61869716
>>61868983

61869731
>>61869678
ive looked at government jobs. i wouldnt dream of working fed govt after trump fired millions of fed workers. state/local pay sucks unless youre at like the director level, but remote is rare and is always subject to some niggerfaggot politician demanding all government wagies return to the wage cage so as to pump jewish commercial real elstate bags.

>>61868983

>>61868983
>What was the "process" even like for you dinosaurs? Did you just walk in, pulse check, firm handshake, and get handed a 250k TC package with stock options?
Yes

61869908
>>61869002
I manage a lot of part-time people and at the time I had a few ask me to limit their hours so they could collect partial unemployment. it was a ridiculous time.

61869996
>>61868983
It was really easy to pump up your salary every month by switching job. Currently stuck since the market got so shit. Not mad since im still profiting. (IT fag)

61870040
I still had to apply to a lot of places. Most of the places avidly hiring were shittier companies or contract roles. But I did get to vault to senior level status after only 4 years of junior because of the demand. Salary went from $78k to $126k total and I got to be fully remote. LinkedIn/Indeed were still fully useable for applications.

Being in tech though the interview process was still shit, multi panel stuff and lots of calls and back and forth with many companies. Not too dissimilar from now except people were more eager to talk to you. I do have almost 10 years experience though so maybe that's why I'm still getting bites these days.

>>61869731

61870415

it was really nice man, lots of recruiters in your DMs all the time asking you to interview and you could leverage it pretty easily
now it's shit compared to back then but hopefully the pendulum swings back at some point

>>61868983

>>61868983

I did have to do math that was probably an IQ test, videos, on-site interviews with hiring managers, tech team, etc... an before that I had idk how many calls with HR.
Most people I know just pray and spray their CVs.
Competent and socially adjusted people are the rarest thing there is.
Stop dooming and apply yourself. Literally

These men are what all men want to be, but sadly most never get to experience such a life.

For most men have weak little flames, the ones that burn very frugally. They don't consume much energy which is why they're prone to becoming skinnyfat. Thin little limbs and a big round belly that retains fuel forever since so little is used in a day.

It's obvious to all bystanders and it instinctively repulses them as lepers do. Women want nothing to do with these hollow husks of men, those who cannot enjoy life.
They're not interested in a smart guy who will live life as efficiently as possible, they want a wild card who isn't afraid of anything. The sort of guy who thinks "New York, sounds like fun!" rather than snorting and citing crime statistics.

Basically, the reason why many women like n**rs is because their flames burn a little stronger than the average civilized man's does.
They're not scared of doing what they like, they're going outside and interacting with the world rather than cooping up indoors and observing life from a safe distance.

The property tax increase 'announcement' is contingent on the governor rejecting a 2% municipal tax on individuals making over 1m/yr, which is bad for people using the loophole someone else mentioned of property tax avoidance. The property tax increase is a statement of the downstream effects of not implementing the proposed tax on high-income earners.

No.
They are not charities, they do not sell at cost, or with a fixed margin, if they could make more charging more, they would already be doing it. The only reason they are not already doing so is simple - competition; if they charge too much, people will go elsewhere, if they can.
Higher property taxes force idle real estate onto the market.

>>61870835
Demand is inelastic, but not that inelastic. People are already at carrying capacity when it comes to rent prices, especially in Jew York City. If market rate for rent rises further, a higher proportion of people will be forced to move away or become homeless.

At some point in this process, landjews will be unable to pass on costs and will have to either rent out their properties for a loss or take an even bigger loss and leave them empty.
